coredata.dc:title: Thickness-dependent layered BiOIO3 modified with carbon quantum dots for photodegradation of bisphenol A: Mechanism, pathways and DFT calculation
coredata.dc:creator: Lai, Jiahao
Jiang, Xinyu
Zhao, Min
Cui, Shihai
Yang, Jing
Li, Yafei
coredata.dc:description:
Semiconductor photocatalysis has a great prospect in solving the problems of environmental pollution. Herein, the thickness-dependent BiOIO3 loaded by carbon quantum dots (CQDs/BiOIO3) was first synthesized. The 3 wt% CQDs/BiOIO3 with sheet-like morphology exhibited the highest efficiency of 95.01 % for the photodegradation of bisphenol A after 60 min. The outstanding photocatalytic activity was ascribed to two aspects: the first was the efficient separation of photogenic e−-h+ in thin layered BiOIO3 (50 nm); the second was the acceleration of charge transfer and the extension of light absorption after the CQDs co-catalysis. The h+ and
O2 − were dominant active species in the degradation process and possible mechanism was deeply studied. The attacked sites of bisphenol A were ascertained by Fukui index and the degradation pathways were proposed through the LC–MS analysis. This work significantly deepens the understanding of layered bismuth-based material and provides ideas for the design of high-performance catalysts.

head.ce:title: Thickness-dependent layered BiOIO3 modified with carbon quantum dots for photodegradation of bisphenol A: Mechanism, pathways and DFT calculation

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
Semiconductor photocatalysis has a great prospect in solving the problems of environmental pollution. Herein, the thickness-dependent BiOIO3 loaded by carbon quantum dots (CQDs/BiOIO3) was first synthesized. The 3 wt% CQDs/BiOIO3 with sheet-like morphology exhibited the highest efficiency of 95.01 % for the photodegradation of bisphenol A after 60 min. The outstanding photocatalytic activity was ascribed to two aspects: the first was the efficient separation of photogenic e−-h+ in thin layered BiOIO3 (50 nm); the second was the acceleration of charge transfer and the extension of light absorption after the CQDs co-catalysis. The h+ and
O2 − were dominant active species in the degradation process and possible mechanism was deeply studied. The attacked sites of bisphenol A were ascertained by Fukui index and the degradation pathways were proposed through the LC–MS analysis. This work significantly deepens the understanding of layered bismuth-based material and provides ideas for the design of high-performance catalysts.

ce:section.ce:para: The increasing global environmental pollution and energy crisis have become the hot issues [1]. Photocatalysis with semiconductors, considered as an environmental purification strategy, has already intensively attracted many concerns because of its prominent application for environmental treatment and energy conversion [2]. Since the discovery of photocatalytic water splitting on TiO2 electrodes by Fujishima and Honda [3], plenty of studies have been conducted on designing and constructing efficient photocatalysts, such as g-C3N4, ZnO, CdS, ATiO3 (A = Ba, Sr), BiOX (X = Cl, Br, I), etc [4–7]. However, there is still a big gap between photocatalytic activity and practical application. The main problems are the high recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs (e−-h+) and the limited light absorption property in the photocatalytic degradation process.

During the long course of development of layered bismuth oxide semiconductors photocatalysts, Aurivillius-phase compounds (General formula: Bi2An-1BnO3n+1) have been widely studied, which are a class of materials consisting of perovskite-like structural units (An-1BnO3n+1)2− and bismuth oxide layers (Bi2O2)2+ [8,9]. As one of the layered bismuth-based (LBB) semiconductors with Aurivillius structure, non-centrosymmetric layered bismuth oxide iodate (BiOIO3) crystal is composed of (Bi2O2)2+ layers and IO3- pyramids (Fig. S1) [10]. The characteristic structure can promote more effective separation of light-induced charges. Thus, BiOIO3 exhibits excellent photocatalytic properties in organic pollutant degradation, nitrogen monoxide and mercury removal [11–13]. Nevertheless, the rapid recombination rate of photogenerated e--h+ in the bulk Bi-based photocatalyst is a key factor which influences the catalytic activities. In this regard, the LBB photocatalyst by building ultrathin structure has been proven to be an available tactic to improve the efficiency of charge separation [14]. Compared with large bulk or high thickness materials, the photoexcited charges inside low thickness layered photocatalysts are easy to migrate to the surface. Plenty of attempts have been made to prepare nanoscale thin-semiconductors to obtain excellent catalytic activity. For instance, Zhang et al. noted that the number of defects in ultrathin BiOCl nanosheets resulted in increased carrier density, which significantly improved the water splitting performance compared with bulk BiOCl [15]. Zuo et al. proposed that the photocatalytic H2 evolution by the ultrathin ZnIn2S4 nanosheets was 6.6 times higher than pristine one, which was ascribed to the enhancement of photogenerated charge transfer and separation [16]. Liang et al. found that the carrier lifetime in the single-unit-cell BiWO6 nanosheets (83.2 ns) was clearly longer than that of the corresponding bulk material (14.7 ns) [17]. Therefore, the construction of thin-layered photocatalysts is beneficial to extremely accelerate the charge transport process. Notably, Wang et al. theoretically demonstrated that the two-dimensional bismuth catalysts are not always “the thinner the better” for CO2 reduction [18]. To acquire a better equilibrium between structure and activity, BiOIO3 with different thickness have been synthesized by adjusting the solution acidity during hydrothermal process.

The relatively wide band gap (3.0–3.3 eV) of BiOIO3 severely limits its response to visible light [19]. To strengthen the light absorption property of BiOIO3, many advantageous strategies have been adopted, such as doping, heterojunction construction, co-catalyst surface modification and morphology control [20]. Among them, the co-catalyst modification is a feasible scheme to settle the existing demerit. As a kind of typically quasi-spherical carbon nanomaterials with the size no more than 10 nm [21], carbon quantum dots (CQDs) have attracted extensive attentions due to its applications in the fields of sensors [22], biological imaging [23], catalysis [24], photovoltaic devices [25] and so on. Meanwhile, CQDs are not only used to adjust controllable band structures for expanding absorption edge, but also recognized as an electron acceptor or buffer to transfer charges from bulk-to-surface. Recently, Feng et.al reported that CdS was coupled with g-C3N4 by employing CQDs as the electron mediator to degrade phenol and dyes [26]. Huang and colleagues found that a variety of surface charged organic contaminants could be degraded by CQDs/ɑ-FeOOH, which was related to the function of coupled up-conversion CQDs [27]. Additionally, CQDs can tightly couple with other semiconductors because of π-conjugated structure and surface oxygen-containing functional groups, for instance, CQDs/TiO2, CQDs/ZnIn2S4 and CQDs/CuCo2O4 [28–30]. Therefore, the photocatalytic performance of BiOIO3 is expected to be improved after CQDs co-catalyst modification.

In this work, the thickness-dependent layered BiOIO3 modified with CQDs were firstly synthesized by controlling the acidity of the reaction solution in the hydrothermal process. A great deal of systematic characterization was employed to investigate the morphology, structure property and composition of nanomaterials. The photocatalytic activities of as-prepared catalysts were evaluated by bisphenol A (BPA) removal under simulated sunlight irradiation. The photocatalytic mechanism was presented based on the results of active species tests and photoelectrochemical analysis. Combined with density functional theory (DFT) calculation, three-dimensional excitation-emission matrix fluorescence spectra (3D-EEMs) and liquid chromatography-mass (LC–MS) analysis, the attacked sites were confirmed and the photodegradation pathways were systematically explored.

Bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (Bi(NO3)3·5H2O, 485.07, AR), nitric acid (HNO3, 63.01, 65.0∼68.0 %, AR) and ethylenediamine (C2H8N2, 60.10, AR) were ordered from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Potassium iodate (KIO3, 214.00, AR) was obtained from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Citric acid (C6H8O7, 192.13, AR) was purchased from Shanghai Adamas Reagent Co., Ltd. All chemicals were analytical grade reagents which were used without further treatment throughout the experiments. All solutions were prepared with water (Hangzhou Wahaha Group Co., Ltd, China).

The CQDs were synthesized through a modified method according to a previous research [31]. Briefly, 1.051 g citric acid and 335 μL ethylenediamine were dissolved in 10 mL ultrapure water, which was continuously magnetic stirred for 10 min at room temperature. Then, the above-obtained suspension was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 5 h. Afterwards, the dark-brown solution was dialyzed in a cellulose ester dialysis membrane (MWCO: 1000) for 24 h and vacuum freeze-dried to gain solid brownish black CQDs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of BiOIO3 and CQDs/BiOIO3 composites
ce:section.ce:para: The layered BiOIO3 with different thickness were synthesized via a hydrothermal procedure. Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (2 mmol) and KIO3 (2 mmol) are dispersed into 60 mL a certain amount of HNO3 solutions with continuously magnetic stirring for 30 min. Then, the mixed solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 150 °C for 15 h. Subsequently, the obtained products were centrifuged, washed and dried at 60 °C for 8 h. For comparison, the 60 mL HNO3 solutions were prepared by adding 1, 2, 3, or 4 mL concentrated HNO3 to the water, respectively. Then the different BiOIO3 materials were obtained and named as BiOIO3-1, BiOIO3-2, BiOIO3-3 and BiOIO3-4.

For the synthesis of CQDs/BiOIO3, Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (2 mmol) and nitric acid (HNO3, 2 mL) were dissolved in 60 mL of ultrapure water. After stirring for 15 min, a certain amount of CQDs and KIO3 (2 mmol) were added into the above solution under continuously magnetic stirring for 30 min. Then, the mixture was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 150 °C for 15 h. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained products were centrifuged and washed with absolute ethanol and ultrapure water several times. The final products were dried in an oven at 60 °C for 8 h. For comparison, 1, 3 and 5 wt% content of CQDs were added for the CQDs/BiOIO3 prepration. Then the composites were denoted as CQB-1, CQB-3 and CQB-5 for convenience. In order to ascertain the real amount of carbon quantum dots loading, element analyzer (Elementar Vario MICRO Cube, Germany) was carried out. As listed in Table S1 in Supplementary Material (SM), the carbon quantum dots contents are about 1.1 wt%, 2.0 wt% and 3.3 wt%, respectively.
The schematic diagram for the material preparation is shown in Fig. 1 .

The crystallinity of as-prepared materials were confirmed by X-ray powder diffractometer (XRD, Cu Kα, 18 kW, voltage 20−60 kV, electrical current 10−300 mA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher Scientific Escalab Xi+, USA) was implemented to investigate the element chemical states of photocatalysts. The microstructure and crystalline structure of the materials were observed by a field emission transmission electron microscope (FE-TEM, JEOL JEM-2100 F, Japan). The surface morphology and distribution conditions of elements were analyzed by scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL JSM-5610LV, Japan) equipped with X-ray energy-dispersive spectroscope (EDS). The nitrogen adsorption measurement principle (Micromeritics ASAP 2020, USA) was employed to detect Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface areas (SBET) of the materials. The functional groups and structure of synthesized catalysts were determined on a FT-IR spectrophotometer (Bruker ALPHA II, Germany). Raman spectra (Bruker RAM II, Germany) were detected by a 532 nm laser beam. Ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflection spectrophotometer (UV–vis DRS, Varian Cary 5000, USA) was used to investigate the optical absorption property. The mineralization ability of material was measured by total organic carbon (TOC) analyzer (Shimadzu VCSN, Japan). Photoluminescence (PL) spectra and 3D-EEMs were recorded on a fluorescence spectrophotometer (PL, Hitachi F-7100 FL, Japan). Time-resolved fluorescence decay spectra were carried out by spectrofluorometer (FluoroMax-4, HORIBA Scientific). The signals of hydroxyl radicals and superoxide radicals were checked on electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR, Bruker EMX 10/12, Germany) spectrometer by 5, 5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) as spin-trap reagent.

The photocatalytic activity of the BiOIO3 and CQDs/BiOIO3 composites were measured by the photodegradation of 10 mg L−1 BPA in the XPA-7 photocatalytic apparatus (Xujiang electromechanical plant, Nanjing, China). In a typical experiment, 30 mL BPA aqueous solution and a certain amount of catalyst were put in a 60 mL quartz glass tube (about 5 cm far from the lamp in a circle). Before irradiation, the suspensions were magnetically stirred in the dark for 60 min to establish adsorption-desorption equilibrium. The 350 W Xenon lamp was used as the light source to simulate sunlight and the wavelength spectrum of Xenon light was presented in Fig. S2, which was located in the center of the circular reactor. At given irradiation time intervals, aliquots of the mixed solution were collected and filtered to remove the catalyst particulates for analysis.

The electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS), transient photocurrent response (i-t) and Mott-Schottky (M-S) curves were implemented on an electrochemical system (CHI-660E, Shanghai Chenhua Instruments Co., Ltd.). The saturated Ag/AgCl electrode and Pt wire were used as reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively. The working electrodes were made by indium-tin oxide (ITO) glass filmed with as-synthesized materials. In detail, 10 mg catalyst fully dispersed in 1 mL absolute ethanol, and then the mixture was added to a 20 × 40 mm ITO dropwise. 0.1 M Na2SO4 and 350 W Xenon lamp were used as electrolyte solution and the light source, respectively.

The BPA concentration was measured by a high performance liquid chromatography system (HPLC, Waters 1525, USA) with the ZORBAX-SB-C18 column (5 μm, 4.6 × 250 mm) and detection wavelength of 278 nm. The mobile phase consisted of methanol and water solution (7:3) with a flow rate of 1.0 mL min−1. The the intermediates of BPA degradation were identified through liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC–MS, 1290 Infinity LC/6460 QQQ MS, Agilent). The HPLC condition was similar to those described above. MS was conducted in the negative ion mode (-) ESI with the range of m/z 100–1000.

DFT calculations were performed on Materials Studio 7.0 program. The geometry optimizations and Cartesian coordinates (Å) of the BPA were conducted by the B3LYP function. Solvent effect of water was taken into consideration in Conduct-like Screening Model (COSMO) with 1.0 × 10−6 eV/atom SFC tolerance. The highest occupied molecular orbits (HOMO), the lowest unoccupied molecular orbits (LUMO), and Fukui index of the BPA were obtained from DMol3 method.

The phase structures of the as-synthesized materials are examined by XRD. In Fig. 2 A, the distinct diffraction peaks of BiOIO3 at 27.36 °, 31.11 °, 31.61 °, 32.46 ° and 32.96 ° can be attributed to (121), (002), (200), (040) and (131) crystal planes of orthorhombic BiOIO3 (ICSD NO. 26-2019), respectively [32]. It is rather remarkable that the crystallinity of four crystal faces from (002) to (131) gradually strengthen with the increase of acidity (Fig. 2B). BiOIO3-1 has the slightly weak diffraction peaks and BiOIO3-4 has the strongest ones. There are no other signals detected, indicating that the photocatalysts were prepared with high purity. As the peak intensity of BiOIO3-2 was much higher than that of CQDs, the diffraction peaks of CQDs could not be obviously observed in CQDs/BiOIO3 composite (Fig. 2C and insets). The (121) peak intensity of CQDs/BiOIO3 composites decreases with the increase of CQDs, indicating that the CQDs might inhibit the growth of BiOIO3 crystal but doesn’t alter the nanostructures of BiOIO3 [33].

The morphology of the BiOIO3-X (X = 1–4) were obtained by SEM. As shown in Fig. 3 A–D, BiOIO3-X was synthesized by controlling the acidity of the reaction solution, which has regular sheet-like microstructures with different thickness. As can be seen from the SEM images, it is clear that the thickness of BiOIO3-1, BiOIO3-2, BiOIO3-3 and BiOIO3-4 are 40 nm, 50 nm, 100 nm and 125 nm, respectively. It is noteworthy that the layered BiOIO3 thickens with the increase of HNO3 content. The growing trend of BiOIO3-X (X = 1–4) thickness is illustrated by the schematic diagram in Fig. 3E, which matches well with analytical results of XRD (Fig. 2A–B).

The microstructure and crystalline structure of materials were clearly observed by FE-TEM. As shown in Fig. 4 A–B, the CQDs have sphere-like morphology with the average diameter about 2.09 nm. In HRTEM image of Fig. 4C, the CQDs own the lattice spacing of 0.208 nm, which is in keeping with the (100) plane of graphitic carbon [34]. From the Fig. 4D, BiOIO3 exhibits sheet-like nanostructures with the lattice space about 0.289 nm, which matches well with the (002) crystal plane in XRD analysis. In the HRTEM of CQDs/BiOIO3 composite (Fig. 4E), several CQDs are found attaching on the surface of the nanosheet, revealing that the CQDs have been successfully coupled with the BiOIO3. The lattice fringes of 0.289 nm and 0.208 nm attribute to the (002) plane in BiOIO3 and (100) plane in CQDs (Fig. 4F), respectively [32]. From element mapping, the Bi, O, I and C are evenly distributed in the composite (Fig. 4G). EDS analysis further provides the contents of each element and the atomic ratio of Bi, I and O is close to the stoichiometric number in BiOIO3 (Fig. 4H).

The surface chemical compositions, valence states and the interaction between CQDs and BiOIO3 were analyzed by XPS. The survey spectrum (Fig. 5 A) of BiOIO3-2 is made up of bismuth (Bi), oxygen (O), iodine (I). The tiny amount of carbon (C) may come from the environment. In the CQB-3, four elements were detected, which is consistent with the mapping and EDS results above. The carbon signal is obviously stronger for the addition of CQDs. In Fig. 5B, the spin-orbit components centered at approximate 158.95 eV and 164.23 eV in BiOIO3-2 are assigned to Bi3+ 4f7/2 and Bi3+ 4f5/2, respectively. The peaks of Bi in the CQB-3 displays a slight shift to higher binding energy, which indicates the surface Bi chemical environment in the composite changes due to the presence of Bi-C interaction [35–37]. In Fig. 5C, the peaks of O 1s high-resolution spectra located at about 530.08 and 532.06 eV belong to the lattice oxygen and surface hydroxyl groups (Bi-O-H), respectively [38]. As presented in Fig. 5D, two characteristic XPS peaks of I5+ can be observed at the binding energies of 623.51 and 635.02 eV, which are ascribed to I5+ 3d5/2 and I5+ 3d3/2, respectively [39]. Additionally, the high-resolution XPS spectra of C 1s for CQB-3 can be divided three peaks. The first one at 284.56 eV is attributed to the CC bonds with graphitic carbons sp2 orbital (Fig. 5E). The other two peaks located at the binding energies of 285.82 and 287.8 eV belong to the COC and CO, respectively [40]. The analysis above reveals the coexistence and tight integration of CQDs and BiOIO3 in the hybrid material.

The possible interactions between CQDs and BiOIO3-2 were ascertained by FT-IR and Raman spectra. As shown in Fig. S3A, the FT-IR was implemented to investigate the variations of functional groups during the preparation process. In the CQDs, abundant groups can be detected on the surface. For instance, the stretching vibrations of OH at 3448 cm−1, CH bond at 2931 cm−1, bending vibrations of NH at 1563 cm−1 and strong vibrational absorption of CO at 1652 cm−1 [27]. In the BiOIO3, the two typical peaks examined at 767 cm−1 and 686 cm−1 are originated from the IO bending vibration. The band located at 515 cm−1 is indexed to Bi-O stretching vibration [41]. For the CQDs/BiOIO3 composites, the characteristic peaks of OH, CO, IO and BiO are also observed, which indicates the successful fabrication of materials.

Raman spectra were adopted to further identify the presence of CQDs in the complex structures of CQDs/BiOIO3. Compared with BiOIO3-2, the disordered sp3 carbon of D-band at 1348 cm−1 and the conjugated sp2 of carbon atoms of G-band at 1610 cm−1 are markedly detected in CQB-3 (Fig. S3B) [42]. Based on the above evidences, it can be proved that the CQDs have been tightly bonded in the layered BiOIO3.

According to Fig. 6 A, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the layered BiOIO3 with different acidity and CQB-3 display typical type IV with a hysteresis loop. The SBET of the BiOIO3-1, BiOIO3-2, BiOIO3-3, and BiOIO3-4 are 16.26, 11.19, 8.97 and 3.79 m2 g−1, respectively. Obviously, the SBET decreases with the increase of HNO3 concentration and materials thickness (Fig. 6B). After the introduction of CQDs, the SBET of CQB-3 is 30.32 m2 g−1, which is much larger than those of BiOIO3. It can be seen that CQDs play a significant role on the specific surface area and actives sites, which is benefit to the efficient photocatalytic degradation of BPA [43].

The absorption of CQDs at different wavelengths can be directly reflected by UV–vis spectrum. As presented in Fig. 7 A, two characteristic peaks can be observed at the wavelength of 243 and 339 nm, which are ascribed to π-π* transition of aromatic sp2 conjugate domains and n-π* electron transitions dominated by surface oxygen-containing functional groups, respectively [44]. The insets display that the CQDs solution is light brow under the irradiation of daylight (left) and bright blue at 365 nm UV lamp excitation (right). This is relevant to the surface state and size effect of CQDs [31].

To determine the internal relationship between fluorescence emission and UV–vis absorption peaks, PL emission spectra of CQDs in aqueous solution were investigated (Fig. 7B, Table S2). It can be noted that the steady blue emission at approximate 434 nm is clearly examined when the excitation wavelength increases from 300 to 340 nm. The slight shift of emission peak and the continuous increase of fluorescence intensity are referred to the electronic transition in topological defect states of CQDs. As the excitation wavelength increases from 360 to 460 nm, the red shift in emission wavelength and the decreases in fluorescence intensity occur. The ordered redshift is due to the narrowing of the π-π* bandgap caused by the increase of the sp2 region, which reduces the electron transitions energy. These results indicate that the as-synthesized CQDs can improve electron transfer performance to obtain highly photocatalytic efficiency [45].

The optical property of BiOIO3 and CQDs/BiOIO3 composites were conducted by UV–vis DRS (Fig. 7C). It is evidently observed that the absorption edge of BiOIO3 is around 400 nm, suggesting that the BiOIO3 is mainly activated by UV light. The stronger absorption regions of the CQDs/BiOIO3 composites can be observed from 410 to 480 nm owing to the existence of the CQDs. It implies that the harvest spectrum of BiOIO3 can be broadened by the introduction of CQDs, thereby effectively enhancing the availability of visible light. The bandgap energies of BiOIO3-X (X = 1–4) and CQB-3 can be confirmed by the Eq. (1) [46]:
(1)
αhν = A(hν - E g)n/2
Where hv, α, A and E g are photon energy, absorption coefficients, constant and band gap, respectively. Both BiOIO3 and CQB-3 are indirect bandgap semiconductors (n = 4) [46]. As shown in Fig. 7D, the E g of BiOIO3 and CQB-3 are determined to be 3.09 and 2.81 eV.

For more comprehensive understanding of the valence band (VB) and conduction band (CB) composition of BiOIO3, the electronic band structure was investigated by partial density of states calculations. As shown in Fig. S4, the electronic state of the VB of BiOIO3 in the energy range from -7.31 to 0.63 eV is mainly ascribed to the strong O 2p state. Meanwhile, the electronic state of the CB in the energy range between 1.62 and 5.71 eV is mainly originated from Bi 6p, I 5p and O 2p states.

M-S was conducted to ascertain flat band potentials (E fb) and band structures of semiconductors. The positive slope of M-S curves in Fig. 7E–F demonstrates that BiOIO3 and CQB-3 are n-type semiconductors [47]. The flat-band potentials of BiOIO3-X (X = 1–4) and CQB-3 are approximately -0.92, -0.83, -0.79, -0.74 and -0.74 eV (vs. Ag/AgCl), respectively, corresponding to -0.72, -0.63, -0.59, -0.54 and -0.54 eV (vs. NHE) (Fig. S5A–C) [48]. The gradually downward shift of CB level reveals the reduction of photoreduction ability (Fig. 8 ). It is generally considered that the E fb is 0.1 eV positive than the CB for n-type semiconductors [49]. Thus, the E CB of BiOIO3-X (X = 1–4) and CQB-3 are -0.82, -0.73, -0.69, -0.64 and -0.64 eV (vs. NHE). Furthermore, the energy of CB (E CB) and VB (E VB) position of BiOIO3-2 and CQB-3 can be calculated by the Eq. (2). The E CB is -0.73 and -0.64 eV, and their E VB are 2.36 and 2.17 eV, respectively.
(2)
E CB = E VB - E g

PL spectra were performed on the photocatalysts to explore the recombination ratio of photogenerated e−-h+ [50]. It is noticeable that BiOIO3 exhibits relatively strong PL signal around 420 nm (Fig. S5D). For comparison, the intensity of PL peaks weakens in the CQDs/BiOIO3 composite, revealing that charge migration occurs between the CQDs and BiOIO3. CQB-3 has the weakest signal, which can effectively restrain the combination of e−-h+ and stimulate the photocatalysis.

To further verify the results above, i-t and EIS analysis were conducted. In Fig. S5E, the BiOIO3 presents a comparatively low photoelectric current response, while the CQDs/BiOIO3 composites show much higher photoelectric current intensity. Additionally, the arc radius of CQB-3 is smallest in the EIS diagram (Fig. S5F), demonstrating that there is lowest resistance in charge transfer [51]. After the comprehensive analysis, it is believed that the introduction of CQDs slows down the recombination of e−-h+. It acts as the charge separation center of the materials and thus boosts the photocatalytic capacities of materials [52].

All the experiments were performed after 60 min adsorption-desorption equilibrium in the dark. The adsorption capacity of the materials for BPA is exhibited in Fig. S6. The photocatalytic performances of various catalysts including BiOIO3-X and CQB-X were ascertained by the degradation of BPA under irradiation of simulated sunlight (Fig. 9 A). The blank experiment manifests that BPA can be hardly degraded without catalysts. Among BiOIO3-X catalysts, BiOIO3-2 has the optimal degradation rate about 90.51 % with comparatively thin lamellar thickness and high specific surface area. Thus BiOIO3-2 is selected as the component of the composites CQB-X. By comparison, the CQB-3 exhibits the superior performance and about 95.01 % BPA can be removed after 60 min irradiation. Additionally, the photocatalytic degradation kinetics of BPA was studied and the results are shown in Fig. 9B. The relationship of the BPA concentration vs the irradiation time accords with the pseudo-first-order kinetics plot. The degradation rates are greatly improved with the introduction of CQDs. The rate constant k of CQB-3 is 0.04994 min−1, which is 1.86 higher than that of BiOIO3-2. The pseudo-first-order constants and relative coefficients are summarized in Table S3.

Catalyst dosage is one of the vital parameters that affect photocatalytic efficiency. As shown in Fig. 9C, the degradation efficiency of BPA enhances with the increase of catalyst dosage from 0.10 to 0.50 g L−1. More catalysts can provide more active site and free radicals, which accelerate the reaction. However, excessive materials show the worse effect. This is due to the shading effect of abundant particles in solution. Small number photons can reach the surface of BPA molecules, which inhibits the photocatalytic process. Therefore, the optimal catalyst dosage of 0.50 g L−1 is selected in the subsequent degradation experiments.

The solution pH affects charges on the surface of the photocatalyst, the aggregation of nanoparticles and the potential of the energy band, thus impact on the removal of contaminants. In Fig. 9D, it is observed that the degradation efficiency of BPA increases first from pH 3 to 9, then decreases at pH 11. Remarkably, the degradation rate is higher when pH is close to neutral. The change is closely relevant to the acidity constant (pKa) of BPA and isoelectric point (pHIEP). As shown in Fig. 9E, the pKa1 and pKa2 of BPA are 9.6 and 10.2, respectively. It exists in molecules without charges at acidic and neutral environment, while in negative form at pH > 9. The pHIEP of CQB-3 is 6.8. At low pH, the IO3 − has oxidizing property and leads to downward movement of the conduction band of materials. It suggests that the production of superoxide radicals is suppressed. Combining to the analysis of Zeta potential in Fig. 9F, the CQB-3 with negative charges in strong alkaline solution has the large electrostatic repulsion to the BPA− or BPA2−, resulting in the lower adsorption of BPA on catalysts (Fig. S7) and inferior photodegradation effect. Hence, the solutions were conducted at pH 7 in the subsequent experiments.

The stability and recyclability of CQB-3 were studied by the degradation of 10 mg L−1 BPA solution. After five cycles the photodegradation efficiency maintains at 88.4 % (Fig. S8A–B), which implies that the composite has a stable performance in the degradation of BPA. Moreover, the materials before and after five times of cyclic experiments were examined by the FT-IR and XRD detection. Comparatively, there are no additional peaks and evident shift appeared in the XRD pattern and FT-IR spectra (Fig. S8C–D). As presented in Fig. S9A–C, the SEM and TEM images demonstrate no obvious changes of the morphology of CQB-3. Additionally, according to the HRTEM images before and after photocatalysis (Fig. 3F and S9D), the CQB-3 also maintains distinct crystal lattice. The results presented above indicate that the CQB-3 exhibited excellent stability in photoactivity, structure and morphology.

TOC is an essential measure to evaluate mineralization ability of the photocatalyst [53]. Fig. S10 displays that the mineralization efficiency of BPA can reach about 27 % and 51 % by CQB-3 within 30 and 60 min, respectively. Additionally, it can be observed that mineralization efficiency is lower than degradation efficiency in the same time, which implies that BPA is not totally degraded after 60 min irradiation, but translated to intermediate byproducts. Nevertheless, it is certain that these intermediate products will fully break down to CO2 and H2O with the increase of photocatalytic degradation time.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Intermediates identification, possible pathway and DFT calculation
ce:section.ce:para: The 3D-EEMs were carried out to further investigate the degradation and mineralization properties of BPA. In Fig. 10 B, the fluorescence intensity of 10 mg L−1 BPA solution with 60 min adsorption in the dark have no distinct changes with that of the original solution in Fig. 10A, demonstrating the good stability of the BPA. As the irradiation time extends to 30 and 60 min (Fig. 10C–D, Table S4), the fluorescent signals at Ex/Em = 275/305 nm gradually strengthen. It suggests that the molecular structure of BPA is destroyed and decomposed into the intermediate products, which was also supported by the TOC analysis.

DFT calculation was implemented to optimize the BPA structures (Fig. 11 A) and the Cartesian coordinates (Å) for BPA were computed by DMol3/B3LYP (Table S5). The HOMO and LUMO orbits of BPA largely centered at the symmetric phenyl rings and the hydrocarbon/phenolic groups, respectively (Fig. 11B). As presented in Fig. 11C, Fukui index (nucleophilic index f + and electrophilic index f −) were adopted to predict the attacked sites of BPA. It was noted that the C2, C4, C7, C8 and C10 (highlighted in orange) with high values were most vulnerable by active radicals. To further verify the calculation, the reaction intermediates were ascertained by LC–MS analysis. Table S6 and Fig. S11A–F show the details of the fragmentation information in mass spectrometry. The molecular ion at m/z = 227 is identified as the deprotonated molecule [(M-H)-] of BPA. There are six deprotonated molecules of BPA degradation intermediates including 4-(prop-1-en-2-yl)phenol (PEYP, m/z = 133), 4-(prop-1-en-2-yl)cyclohexa-3,5-diene-1,2-dione (CDD, m/z = 147), monohydroxylated BPA (MHBPA, m/z = 243), dihydroxylated BPA (DHBPA, m/z = 259), 2,2-bis(3,4-hydroxyphenyl)-1-propanol (BHP, m/z = 261) and (Z)-3-(1-hydroxy-1-(4-hydroxyphenyl)ethyl) hexa-2,4-dienedioic acid (ZHDA, m/z = 277). Based on the identified intermediates and Fukui index, the possible reaction pathways were proposed in Fig. 12 . Firstly, the electron density on each benzene ring increases due to the electron donating of double hydroxyl groups. The CC bonds linking the isopropyl and two benzene rings in BPA are relatively vulnerable to be electrophilic attacked due to the maximum f − of C7 and C8. Therefore, the β-cleavage occurs, forming IPP (m/z = 133) and CDD (m/z = 147). Secondly, the phenolic radicals (C2, C4 and C10) with high f + are inclined to be oxidized by hydrophilic molecules (
OH) to form MHBPA (m/z = 243). Meanwhile, the aromatic rings are also attacked by
O2 − through the nucleophilic effect, which contributes to a variety of multihydroxylation reactions (m/z = 259 and m/z = 261). The hydroxylated BPA then undergoes dehydration and ring-opening reactions to generate quinone and carboxylic compounds (m/z = 241 and m/z = 277) [54]. Finally, aromatic compounds are subsequently transformed to ring-opened intermediates, which can be eventually mineralized [55]. In conclusion, the reaction paths mainly include the scission of CC between the isopropyl and benzene rings, the (mono-/multi-) hydroxylation of the aromatic ring via electrophilic/nucleophilic attack and further oxidation.

The contribution of different active species was identified during the degradation of BPA by CQB-3 composite. The trapping experiments were implemented to quench h+,
O2 − and
OH by adding the ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid disodium salt (EDTA-2Na), benzoquinone (BQ) and isopropanol (IPA), respectively (Fig. S12A) [56]. The degradation of BPA has a tiny decrease when the IPA is added, demonstrating that
OH takes a relatively minor but nonnegligible impact. Nevertheless, the removal efficiency of BPA is dramatically inhibited after the introduction of EDTA-2Na or BQ, indicating that h+ and
O2 − are main active species in the degradation.

To further quantitatively evaluate the generation of
OH, the photoluminescence technique of CQB-3 was examined with terephthalic acid (TA) as a probe molecule. The addition reaction of
OH and TA can produce stable product 2-hydroxyterephthalic acid (TAOH) with strong fluorescence at Ex/Em = 315/425−432 nm [57]. The amount of
OH can be indirectly determined by measuring the fluorescence intensity of TAOH. In Fig. S12B, the characteristic peaks of TAOH at different irradiation time are very weak. It is apparent that
OH is not the major active species in the decomposition process of BPA, which is also supported by the result of
OH capturing experiment.

The EPR were applied to examine the
O2 − and
OH with DMPO as spin-trapping [58]. It is obvious that no signals of free radical can be found in the dark. However, the DMPO-
O2 − are markedly observed after 2 and 5 min irradiation, revealing that massive
O2 − can be produced (Fig. S12C). Additionally, the signal intensity of
OH has slightly change after 5 min irradiation (Fig. S12D). Based on the experiments above, the
O2 − and h+ are main active species and
OH act as secondary role.

BiOIO3 nanosheets with adjustable thickness were synthesized by controlling the acidity of reaction solution in the hydrothermal process. It was reported that the bottom and top surfaces of layered bismuth-based (LBB) materials expose Bi atoms from the [Bi2O2] layers [59]. Thus, the decreased thickness of the nanosheets with decreased acidity can be accribed to more adsorbed substance on the surface of Bi atoms. The growth of the [Bi2O2] layer was inhibited. The electronic properties of 2D materials have a close relationship with thickness, due to the quantum confinement effect [60]. In general, most of 2D catalysts composed of heavy elements have strong SOC effect, which has a very significant impact on the photoelectric properties. In this regard, as a nanosheet containing heavy elements Bi, BiOIO3 has remarkable SOC effect and photoelectric properties related with the thickness [61,62]. To obtain some insights into the photoelectric properties of BiOIO3 with different thickness, a string of photoelectrochemical characterizations have been investigated. Firstly, in the photoluminescence (PL) spectra (Fig. S5D), BiOIO3-2 had the weakest emission intensity among all BIOIO3-X materials, indicating the lowest recombination rate of photogenerated charges. Secondly, as shown in Fig. S5E-F, the photocurrent response and electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) showed a trend of first increasing and then decreasing intensity. The strongest photocurrent density of BiOIO3-2 is approximately 1.2, 1.6 and 2.1 times higher than that of BIOIO3-X (X = 1, 3, 4), respectively, demonstrating the more efficient charge separation. Additionally, BiOIO3-2 exhibited the smallest arc radius among BiOIO3-X, which aligned well with the PL and photocurrent results. Thirdly, to further investigate the photogenerated carrier transfer dynamics of BiOIO3-X (X = 1–4), time-resolved fluorescence decay spectra were measured at Ex/Em = 265/405 nm. As shown in Fig. 13 A–D, fluorescence decay curves were fitted well with the biexponential function (3) and the average lifetime was calculated by the Eq. (4) [63]:
(3) I(t) = I0 + A1exp(-t/τ1) + A2exp(-t/τ2)
(4) τavg. = (A1τ1 2 + A2τ2 2) / (A1τ1 + A2τ2)
Where I, A, and τ were fluorescence intensity, amplitude and fluorescence lifetime, respectively. It can be seen that the average lifetime (Ave.) of BiOIO3-2 (0.877 ms) is greatly prolonged in comparison with those of BiOIO3-1 (0.820 ms), BiOIO3-3 (0.720 ms) and BiOIO3-4 (0.699 ms), indicating the greatly depressed recombination of photogenerated e−-h+ in BiOIO3-2. Overall, BiOIO3-2 with 50 nm thickness showed the highest activity, which reveal that it had the most pronounced SOC effcet among the BiOIO3 nanosheets.

On the basis of the above discussions, the feasible photodegradation mechanism of CQB-3 composite was schematically illustrated in Fig. 14 . The BiOIO3 has the band gap of 3.09 eV and can only absorb UV illumination. After the combination of CQDs, the band gap CQDs/BiOIO3 reduces to 2.81 eV and the adsorption region is extended to visible light, which is well supported by the optical analysis in Fig. 7C–D. Under simulated sunlight illustration, the electrons with the energy can migrate to the E CB of CQB-3, leaving the holes on the E VB. The CQDs are generally regarded as electron reservoir [64]. Thus the electrons can transfer from the E CB of CQB-3 to the LUMO of CQDs. The recombination of photogenerated charges can be effectively restrained. According to M-S curves in Fig. 7F, the E CB of CQB-3 (-0.64 eV) is more negative than E ө (O2/
O2 −) (-0.33 eV) [65,66], which indicates that the photogenerated electrons can react with O2 to generate
O2 − and oxidize BPA molecules directly. Additionally, the E CB of CQB-3 (2.17 eV) is lower than that of E ө (
OH/H2O) (2.27 eV) [67], suggesting that the
OH derive from the electron induced multistep reduction of O2 instead of direct hole oxidation. Concretely, the dissolved oxygen (O2) adsorbed on catalyst surface can be reduced to
O2 −, further to H2O2. Partial of the generated H2O2 may be dissociated to
OH. These processes accelerate the depletion of electrons, regenerate more oxygen on the surface of catalyst, promote the generation of
O2 −, and facilitate the efficient separation of photogenerated carriers. Therefore, the BPA molecules will be attacked by
O2 −,
OH and h+, resulting in the generation of intermediate products, CO2 and H2O. The possible reaction routes of photocatalytic processes have been proposed and described as Eqs. (5–9):
(5) CQB-3 + hv → e− + h+
(6) e− + O2 →
O2 −
(7)
O2 − + e− + 2H+ → H2O2
(8) H2O2 + e− →
OH + OH-
(9) BPA + h+/
O2 −/
OH → Intermediates + CO2 + H2O

In summary, thickness-dependent BiOIO3 modified CQDs have been successfully fabricated through hydrothermal method. Photoelectron properties, morphology changes and structural characterizations of the CQDs/BiOIO3 nanomaterials have been studied. About 95.01 % BPA was effectively photodegraded by CQB-3 in 60 min under simulated sunlight illumination at the optimum conditions (catalyst dosage: 15 mg; pH: 7; thickness of BiOIO3: 50 nm). The rate constant was 0.04994 min−1, which is higher than that of BiOIO3. The photocatalytic mechanism was proposed through free radical trapping experiment,
OH quantification test and EPR analysis, demonstrating that
O2 − and h+ played major role and
OH acted as secondary role in degradation reaction. The distinguished photoactivity of the material was ascribed to the layered BiOIO3 (50 nm thickness) and CQDs modification. Integrating DFT calculation and LC–MS analysis, the vulnerable active sites of BPA were identified and the feasible photodegradation pathways were proposed. This work not only provides some promising insight into the CQDs modified 2D layered bismuth-based semiconductors with enhanced photoactivity in organic pollutant degradation, but also opens a new avenue for the fabrication of high-activity catalyst, which can be applied to environmental pollution, energy and other related fields.
